key_points: City workers removed barricades at George Floyd Square, signaling its reopening to public traffic.
George Floyd Square became a memorial and a movement's headquarters after Derek Chauvin knelt on Floyd's neck, leading to Floyd's death.
Residents and activists had fortified the area with makeshift barriers, turning it into a symbol of resistance and memorial.
Chauvin was convicted on two counts of murder and one count of manslaughter, receiving a sentence of 22.5 years in prison.
The trial of the three other officers involved is forthcoming, with federal indictments handed down against all four.
There's a disparity in reactions to the Chauvin conviction; some see it as justice, others as insufficient given broader systemic issues.
Prosecutors in Chauvin's trial included Jerry Blackwell and Steve Schleicher, eliciting significant testimony highlighting Chauvin's actions as unacceptable.
Medaria Arradondo, Minneapolis's first Black police chief, testified that Chauvin's actions didn't align with police ethics or values.
Keith Ellison took over the case, with his involvement seen as a tactical move that brought credibility among progressives.
The conviction of Mohamed Noor, a Black officer, in the killing of Justine Damond posed a contrast to other cases involving white officers.
spokespersons: Jay Webb (Gardener and Caretaker of George Floyd Square)
Medaria Arradondo (First Black Police Chief, Minneapolis)
Richard Zimmerman (Head, Minneapolis Police Department's Homicide Unit)
